moves.1. g4: One of my favorite "oddball" openings, the Grob. White must be careful when using it, as it does expose the K-side somewhat.
moves.1... d5: The Classical response to the Grob.
moves.2. Bg2: A playable line for White, but as this game shows, dangerous if mishandled.
moves.3... c6: Guarding, and preventing a potential BxNP trapping the R... which can easily be overlooked.
moves.4. Qb3: Threatening to win back the Pawn and exchange Queens, neutralizing the potential for a quick Black strike at the White K-side.
moves.4... Qc7: Preventing the potential Q exchange and targeting the K-side.
moves.5... cxd5: ...and completing it. This move contains a hidden threat...
moves.6. Bxd5: ...which White, in his eagerness to snatch back the Pawn, completely overlooks.
moves.6... Qxc1+: The move Lippens missed in his haste. After 7 Q-Q1 QxQ ch 8 KxQ, Smit would be a clear piece up. Lippens resigns.
